Unruly

Western Maryland, for the last several years, has not displayed
what is known as clean football. Spectators of the 1922 clash, especially, Will recall the tactics which caused frequent penalties and left
an unpleasant remembrance in the minds of local sport lovers.
Western Maryland has hot defeated Hopkins on the gridiron
since the days of "Holly" Keller and it is unlikely that the Westminster College will ever 'again be in a position to claim the State
Championship. This being the case, there is little to be gained
from keeping them on the schedule. Hopkins' activities need national
advertising and the fact that the Homewood team has defeated Western Maryland does not cause sprea'ds to appear in newspapers out of
the city.
The student body would not have approved of a last moment's
cancellation of Saturday's game. With Western Maryland's reputed
prowess it might have appeared as if Hopkins was afraid of the
consequences. There are few, however, who will bemoan the fact
that the "Green Terrors" will not be seen at Homewood Field next
fall.

SACRILEGE?
There is a rumor existing that there will be no parade on Saturday morning preceding the St. John's game. This.parade is a tradition
which has existed since the Black and Blue and the St. Johnnie's
first clashed. Alumni from far back can recall marching through the
streets of Baltimore and predicting the fate of St. John's to the
people of the Monumental City.
We feel that the omission of this parade would be sacrilegious.

GEOLOGY CLASS TAKES A
TRIP TO MT. WASHINGTON AND WOODBERRY
Students, in Search of Young Streams,
Tramp Through Suburbs of
Baltimore

The students of Geology I, under the guidance of Dr. Hall, instructor in Geology, took a long
tramp last -Wednesday afternoon
in search of streams in varying
stages of development. Starting
at 1:00 o'clock from the campus,
the group progressed westward
across Wyman's Park Driveway,
over the railroad tracks, to the
Mt. Vernon-Woodberry Mills.
, Here, a stream in infancy, the
Jones' Falls, was observed. Specimens of rock, such as Baltimore
gneiss and pigmatite, were also
collected at this point.
The party then proceeded to
Hampden, where they boarded a
street car and the group went to
Bare Hills. Here, a stream in maturity, exhibiting flood plains and
meanders, was observed. Lake
Roland, further up Stream, was
then discussed and several stu• dents with cameras took pictures.
In order to enable students on
the football squad to re-turn to the
campus• in time for practice, Dr.
Schwartz has arranged a plan
whereby machines will be sent
out to bring the men in.
The trip described above was
repeated last Friday afternoon by
another group under the guidance
of Professor Schwartz.

WILLIAM KONRAD ROENTGEN
1845-1923
Born in Lennep,Prussia. Educated at Zurich. Awarded the
Rumford Medal of the Royal
Society in 1896 jointly with
Philip Lenard for discovery of
X-rays. Won the Nobel Prize
in physics in 1901.

One day in 1895, Roentgen noticed that a
cardboard coated with fluorescent material
glowed while a nearby Pluecker tube was
in action. "What did you think?" an
English scientist asked him. "I did not
think; I investigated," was the reply.
Roentgen covered the tube with black
paper. Still the cardboard glowed. He took
photographs through a pine door and discovered on them a white band corresponding to the lead beading on the door. His
investigation led to the discovery of X-rays.

The General Electric
Company manufactures
everything electric—
from fans to powerful
locomotives, from tiny
lamps to mighty power
plants. Its products are
used around the world.

Roentgen's rays have proved an inestimable boon to humanity. In the hands of
doctor and surgeon they are saving life
and reducing suffering. In the hands of
the scientist they are yielding new knowledge — even of the arrangement and
structure of atoms. The Research Laboratories of the General Electric Company
have contributed greatly to these ends by
developing more powerful and efficacious
X-ray tubes.

Western Maryland, for the last several years, has not displayed
what is known as clean football. Spectators of the 1922 clash, especially, Will recall the tactics which caused frequent penalties and left
an unpleasant remembrance in the minds of local sport lovers.
Western Maryland has hot defeated Hopkins on the gridiron
since the days of "Holly" Keller and it is unlikely that the Westminster College will ever 'again be in a position to claim the State
Championship. This being the case, there is little to be gained
from keeping them on the schedule. Hopkins' activities need national
advertising and the fact that the Homewood team has defeated Western Maryland does not cause sprea'ds to appear in newspapers out of
the city.
The student body would not have approved of a last moment's
cancellation of Saturday's game. With Western Maryland's reputed
prowess it might have appeared as if Hopkins was afraid of the
consequences. There are few, however, who will bemoan the fact
that the "Green Terrors" will not be seen at Homewood Field next
fall.

SACRILEGE?
There is a rumor existing that there will be no parade on Saturday morning preceding the St. John's game. This.parade is a tradition
which has existed since the Black and Blue and the St. Johnnie's
first clashed. Alumni from far back can recall marching through the
streets of Baltimore and predicting the fate of St. John's to the
people of the Monumental City.
We feel that the omission of this parade would be sacrilegious.

GEOLOGY CLASS TAKES A
TRIP TO MT. WASHINGTON AND WOODBERRY
Students, in Search of Young Streams,
Tramp Through Suburbs of
Baltimore

The students of Geology I, under the guidance of Dr. Hall, instructor in Geology, took a long
tramp last -Wednesday afternoon
in search of streams in varying
stages of development. Starting
at 1:00 o'clock from the campus,
the group progressed westward
across Wyman's Park Driveway,
over the railroad tracks, to the
Mt. Vernon-Woodberry Mills.
, Here, a stream in infancy, the
Jones' Falls, was observed. Specimens of rock, such as Baltimore
gneiss and pigmatite, were also
collected at this point.
The party then proceeded to
Hampden, where they boarded a
street car and the group went to
Bare Hills. Here, a stream in maturity, exhibiting flood plains and
meanders, was observed. Lake
Roland, further up Stream, was
then discussed and several stu• dents with cameras took pictures.
In order to enable students on
the football squad to re-turn to the
campus• in time for practice, Dr.
Schwartz has arranged a plan
whereby machines will be sent
out to bring the men in.
The trip described above was
repeated last Friday afternoon by
another group under the guidance
of Professor Schwartz.

"I did not think
I investigated"
WILLIAM KONRAD ROENTGEN
1845-1923
Born in Lennep,Prussia. Educated at Zurich. Awarded the
Rumford Medal of the Royal
Society in 1896 jointly with
Philip Lenard for discovery of
X-rays. Won the Nobel Prize
in physics in 1901.

One day in 1895, Roentgen noticed that a
cardboard coated with fluorescent material
glowed while a nearby Pluecker tube was
in action. "What did you think?" an
English scientist asked him. "I did not
think; I investigated," was the reply.
Roentgen covered the tube with black
paper. Still the cardboard glowed. He took
photographs through a pine door and discovered on them a white band corresponding to the lead beading on the door. His
investigation led to the discovery of X-rays.

The General Electric
Company manufactures
everything electric—
from fans to powerful
locomotives, from tiny
lamps to mighty power
plants. Its products are
used around the world.

Roentgen's rays have proved an inestimable boon to humanity. In the hands of
doctor and surgeon they are saving life
and reducing suffering. In the hands of
the scientist they are yielding new knowledge — even of the arrangement and
structure of atoms. The Research Laboratories of the General Electric Company
have contributed greatly to these ends by
developing more powerful and efficacious
X-ray tubes.
